headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Walt Disney First Quarter Fiscal Year '16 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Bianca, and I will be your operator for this call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to your h
componenttext: Welcome to the Walt Disney First Quarter Fiscal Year '16 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Bianca, and I will be your operator for this call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to your host, Mr. Lowell Singer, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Singer, you may begin.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Walt Disney Company's first quarter 2016 earnings call. Our press release was issued about 40 minutes ago and is available on our website at www.disney.com/investors. Today's call is also being webcast and a replay and a
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Walt Disney Company's first quarter 2016 earnings call. Our press release was issued about 40 minutes ago and is available on our website at www.disney.com/investors. Today's call is also being webcast and a replay and a transcript will be available on our website. 
Joining me for today's call are Bob Iger, Disney's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Tom Staggs, Chief Operating Officer; and Christine McCarthy, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Bob, Tom and Christine  will each make some comments and then, of course, we will be happy to take your questions. So with that, let the turn the call over to Bob and we'll get started be.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lowell, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm thrilled to announce that our Q1 performance was the greatest single quarter in the history of the Walt Disney Company and a phenomenal start to fiscal 2016. Revenue was up 14%, net income was up 32% and a
componenttext:
Thanks, Lowell, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm thrilled to announce that our Q1 performance was the greatest single quarter in the history of the Walt Disney Company and a phenomenal start to fiscal 2016. Revenue was up 14%, net income was up 32% and adjusted earnings per share were up 28% to $1.63, which is our highest quarterly EPS ever and is also our 10th consecutive quarter of double-digit EPS growth. 
We had tremendous performance across our portfolio of businesses with the incredible success of Star Wars: The Force Awakens, our studio delivered $1 billion in quarterly operating income for the first time in history. Our Parks and Resorts also made history with nearly $1 billion in operating income. And our Consumer Products and interactive business set another record with $816 million NOI. Our results clearly show that our long-term strategic focus and investments in brands and franchises are driving remarkable value in these businesses, greatly increasing their impact on the company and further diversifying our future growth.
Over the last 10 years, we've built an enviable collection of vibrant, valued and admired brands. We've also created, acquired or re-envisioned several of the world's most valuable franchises and we're fully leveraging these assets across our portfolio of businesses and around the globe. 
Of course, nothing reflects the impact of this strategy better than the phenomenal resurgence of the Star Wars franchise, and there is no better way to propel this franchise into the future than producing quality products. It's been absolutely thrilling to see the reaction to our first Star Wars feature film, The Force Awakens. Audiences and critics alike really love this movie. It's only film in history to ever reach 900 million in domestic box office. And as you may have heard, it crossed $2 billion in global box office over the weekend, more than doubling the worldwide box office for the last Star Wars release a decade ago. 
Breaking records at the box office is only the beginning. Global retail sales for Star Wars merchandise in the first quarter exceeded $3 billion, more than triple the global retail for this franchise in Q1 of last year. Star Wars is also driving unprecedented growth for our mobile games and EA's launch of Star Wars: Battlefront was the biggest video game release in Star Wars' history with more than 13 million units sold. 
Building of Star Wars: Episode VIII, the next chapter of the legendary saga has just commenced and will be in theaters December 2017. And production of Episode IX, the 2019 release, has also begun. In the meantime, we'll keep fans engaged in the Star Wars universe and further expand the franchise with the release of Rogue One this coming December. It's a compelling and original standalone story about a band of rebels attempting to steal the plans to the Death Star that just prior to the events in the very first Star Wars movie, Episode IV, A New Hope. Filming of Rogue One is virtually completed and we absolutely love what we've seen so far. This is the first of a set of planned standalone stories and we're already in preproduction on our next one for release in May of 2018.
And on the parks from later this year, we'll break ground on spectacular new Star Wars theme land in Disneyland and Walt Disney World. Clearly, Q1 saw the impact of our extremely successful relaunch of the Star Wars franchise, as well as its enormous potential to drive value across our entire company for the foreseeable future. Given our unparalleled make some of the world's best IP and strongest brands, we're well-positioned for continued growth over the long term regardless of changing dynamics in the media landscape.
Now turning to a subject that has gotten a lot of attention lately, ESPN and the status of the bundle. In the last couple of months, we've actually seen an uptick in ESPN subs which is encouraging. We're also pleased with what we're hearing from DISH about the response of Sling TV, a light package that includes ESPN. The service appears to be very nicely and is proving very attractive to younger consumers in particular. Significantly over indexing among millennials. And has been quite successful in bringing previous cord cutters back to pay-TV along with new subscribers. Sling TV is clearly additive to the robust MVPD universe and our networks benefit accordingly. The popularity of sports and the strength of ESPN add great value for consumers who want lighter packages and we're currently in discussions with new and existing distribution partners to create an array of innovative new services and light packages featuring ESPN.
We will continue to focus on subscriber trends, moving quickly to embrace and create opportunities to drive value in the evolving market. It's interesting to note that Nielsen has significantly lowered its estimate of losses of multichannel households in 2015. Regardless in any market, we believe ESPN is well-positioned to continue to thrive for many reasons, including: the demand for sports programming especially live sports, is undiminished and consumption is at an all-time high. Last year, 95% of Americans with a multichannel bundle watched sports, and 81% of those viewers watch ESPN content. Across all platforms, more than 200 million adults engaged with ESPN in an average month. In other words, 4 out of 5 adults in this country connected with ESPN on some platform every month, usually more than 1. ESPN has is the sports and most people want. It holds more national sports rights than all other sports media combined, and it has the most important rights secured to the next decade, including the NFL, the NBA, Major League Baseball and the most coveted college sports. 
Consumers, advertisers and operators see great value in ESPN. The vast majority of consumers still see tremendous value in the multichannel universe and they consistently rank ESPN as the #1 or #2 most valuable channel within it. ESPN's ad revenue continues to grow, thanks to its proven ability to reach audiences that advertisers value most. In fact, ESPN's ad sales significantly outpaced the market, growing 3x faster than television advertising overall over the last 6 years. MVPD has just ranked ESPN #1 in perceived value for the 16th year in a row, due in part to the fact that ESPN drives more local ad sales and broadband subscriptions than any other service in the market.
The expanded basic bundle will remain the dominant product for consumers further for the foreseeable future. The competition from new video services and products will only grow. Better user interfaces and greater mobility make these newer services enormously appealing, especially among young people. And many of our brands, including Disney, Marvel, Star Wars and ESPN are tailor-made for over-the-top, direct-to-consumer app-based video products, so expect innovation and continued pursuit of new distribution opportunities.
Our results this quarter clearly demonstrate that our focus on higher quality branded content and franchises to diversify our asset mix, our ability to use technology to aggressively create new opportunities and our ambitious global growth are paying off with record performance. We're proud of our achievements, we're excited about the future and we're confident our ability to continue to drive growth across the entire company. 
I'm going to do the call over to Tom to walk you through some highlights across the company, and then Christine will take you through the details of our performance in Q1. Tom?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Hello, everyone. As Bob just highlighted, the strength of our branded programming networks gives us confidence in our ability to continue to grow our Media Networks business. In addition, the marketplace offers a range of other new opportunit
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Hello, everyone. As Bob just highlighted, the strength of our branded programming networks gives us confidence in our ability to continue to grow our Media Networks business. In addition, the marketplace offers a range of other new opportunities for us. They include our continued investment in the future of Hulu as both a compelling consumer platform and another active buyer of high-quality content; our investment in and collaboration with Vice; our distributable agreement with AliBaba for DisneyLife in China; and ESPN's undertaking with Tencent in China as well. Our opportunistic approach also led to a successful Marvel series on Netflix, which helps extend the Marvel franchise and broaden its reach. 
As importantly, after a decade of strategic value-creating acquisitions and capital allocation, our other businesses have grown significantly increasing their impact on our results. This purposeful diversification across branded franchises with attractive long-term potential, along with an aggressive approach towards leveraging new technologies and driving global growth, are the key strategies we laid out a decade ago. With branded content from Disney, ESPN, ABC, Pixar, Marvel and Star Wars, we have the most valuable collection of branded franchises and other high-impact IP in the world, and few companies have embraced the promise of new technology as enthusiastically and effectively as ours.
These strategies are bearing significant fruit today continue to guide our path for the future. We've invested heavily over the last several years to significantly expand our Parks and Resorts business. Those efforts include: the creation of Cars Land and transformation of Disney California Adventure; introducing MyMagic+ and doubling the size of Fantasyland at Walt Disney World; doubling the size of our cruise fleet; and adding 3 new lands in Hong Kong. The record results for the quarter, which include all-time high global attendance, record results for our domestic parks and our best Q1 results ever for Disney Cruise Line, reflect the impacts and value creation of these investments. 
We're already benefiting from the success of Star Wars at our parks as well. Since December, more than 6 million guests of experience new and refreshed Star Wars attractions and features in our parks. And this year, we're rolling out even more theme attractions from Parks and Resorts around the world, including Star Wars Day at Sea which debuted on the Disney Fantasy last month. 
Our most important single new initiative at Parks is Shanghai Disneyland, which will have its grand opening on June 16. Tickets will officially go on sale on March 28. Announcement that has been incredibly well received in China. Bob and I were over there and we couldn't be more pleased or excited with how well our preparations are going. Thousands of new -- have already been hired. Ride testing has started on the attractions and anticipation is palpable and growing. Shanghai Disney Resort is going to be tremendous source of pride for everyone involved. It's one of the most extraordinarily creative and innovative projects in the history of our company, which makes it a perfect way to firmly establish Disney in the hearts and minds of the people of China, as well as an attractive and profitable place to deploy our capital for the long term.
Our franchise focused strategy is driving growth across the company, including our Consumer Products and Interactive business. Star Wars is obviously a huge driver for Consumer Products interactive results for the quarter but wasn't the only one. We're also very pleased with licensing growth this quarter from Marvel led by Avengers. As we discussed previously, we have 11 franchises that generate more than $1 billion each in annual retail sales over the last 2 fiscal years, making our Consumer Products business uniquely broad and deep. 
Our positions at Pixar, Marvel and Lucasfilm give us some of the most valuable IP in the world. They also brought some of the world's most gifted storytellers and innovators to Disney and marking even more creative potential across the company. 
Bob touched on the ambitious slate of upcoming Star Wars films, but that's just one aspect of our incredible studios pipeline. We have 2 films from Disney feature animation this calendar year started with Disney Animation's Zootopia, an incredibly original, charming and very funny movie opening March 4t. This Thanksgiving, we'll release Moana, a comedy adventure with incredible music, very much in keeping with the tremendous legacy from Disney Animation. As you know, a sequel of Frozen is in the works. In the meantime, Disney Animation is creating the first-ever Frozen -- special which will air on ABC during the 2017 holiday season. And following the tradition of Lion King, Beauty and the Beast and Aladdin, we have new Frozen stage musical slated for Broadway in 2018.
Turning back to animation, we just celebrated the 10th anniversary of our Pixar acquisition. Pixar, and our incredibly talented colleagues there, have possibility impacted every aspect of our company and contributed mightily to our success. Looking ahead, Pixar has as strong a lineup of films as we've ever seen. Finding Dory, the long-awaited sequel to Pixar's beloved movie, Finding Nemo, opens this June. 2017 will bring us Cars 3, plus another Pixar original film set in Latin America called Cocoa. In 2018 comes Toy Story 4 followed by Incredibles 2 the 2019. 
From Disney live-action, this April, we'll bring Mougli, Balou and a host of other classic characters to life in a new way with the release of The Jungle Book. Johnny Depp returns this May as the Mad Hatter in Alice Through the Looking Glass. And again in 2017 as Jack Sparrow for our fifth installment in the hugely successful Pirates of the Caribbean franchise. 2017 will also feature Disney's live-action version of Beauty and the Beast. In addition, we have fantastic slate of Marvel movies that extends through the end of the decade. Captain America and Iron Man face off in an epic battle when Captain America: Civil War opens in May. The movie features some of the most popular Marvel heroes and we believe will prove to be one of our best Marvel movies yet. In November, we're launching another comparing character to the Marvel cinematic universe with the release of Doctor Strange starring Benedict Cumberbatch.
Marvel's Guardians of the Galaxy return next year along with Thor: Ragnarok. And 2018, we'll release 3 more Marvel movies: Black Panther; Avengers: Infinity War; and Ant Man and the Wasp. And with more than 7,000 characters in the Marvel universe, you can expect the Marvel storytelling to continue. We're excited about the future of all of our great brands and the opportunity they provide to drive a continued growth and value for our company across our businesses around the world and through platforms, both old and new. 
Now, I'll turn the call over to Christine to walk you for our results in more detail. Christine?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. It's worth noting again. Fiscal 2016 is off to a phenomenal start. We delivered strong revenue growth, up 14% during the first quarter to a record $15.2 billion. Earnings per share, excluding items affecting comp
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. It's worth noting again. Fiscal 2016 is off to a phenomenal start. We delivered strong revenue growth, up 14% during the first quarter to a record $15.2 billion. Earnings per share, excluding items affecting comparability, were up 28% to a record $1.63. Studio Entertainment had its most profitable quarter ever, and that's following record full year results in fiscal 2015. Operating income was up 86% to over $1 billion. The growth in operating income was primarily due to the fantastic worldwide theatrical performance of Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Home entertainment and television distribution results were also up in the quarter, demonstrating our studio strategy continues to create value beyond the theatrical window. 
The success of Star Wars at the box office also drove increased demand for Star Wars merchandise. Operating income at the recently combined Disney Consumer Products and Interactive Media segment was up 23% and segment margins were up over 500 basis points to 45% driven by the growth in the Merchandise Licensing and games primarily on the strength of Star Wars. 
On a comparable basis, earned licensing revenue was up an impressive 23% in the first quarter and that doesn't include the deferred revenue from Star Wars: Episode VII merchandise sold in the fourth quarter of last year. The growth in games was due to higher licensing revenue from Star Wars: Battlefront, partially offset by lower Infinity results. The Disney stores also benefited from sales of Star Wars merchandise. However, the increase in the quarter was offset by very strong sales of Frozen merchandise in Q1 last year.
At Parks and Resorts, operating income was up 22% in the first quarter in reflects the favorable timing of the New Year's holiday period relative to our fiscal calendar, which we discussed in last quarter's call. We estimate this shifted about $90 million in operating income into Q1 this year that was recognized in 2Q last year. 
Our Domestic operations had another great quarter. We continue to see strong demand from guests, specifically at our Domestic parks and at Disney Cruise Line. Attendance at our Domestic parks was up 10% in the quarter and per capita spending was up 7% on higher admissions, food and beverage and merchandise spending. Per room spending at our Domestic hotels was up 9% and occupancy was up 3 percentage points to 92%. Our cruise business had its best Q1 ever, driven by higher ticket pricing and onboard spending, and that's despite a 3-week dry dock of the Disney Dream. Growth in Domestic operations was partially offset by a decline at our international parks as a result of lower operating income at Disneyland Paris, which was closed for 4 days in November, as well as preopening spending at Shanghai.
So far this quarter, Domestic resort reservations are pacing up 2% compared to prior year levels, while booked rates are up 4%. 
At Media Networks, operating income was lower in the first quarter compared to prior year. However, operating income would have grown in line with 8% revenue growth we delivered when adjusted for the timing of the College Football Playoff and an adverse impact from foreign exchange. Results in our cable business were lower in the first quarter as higher programming and production costs offset increases in advertising and affiliate revenue. The higher costs in Q1, which we discussed on our Q4 earnings call, were due to the timing of the 6 New Year's Eve and New Year's Day College Football Playoff bowl game, including the 2 semifinal games which aired on ESPN. These games aired during the first fiscal quarter this year, whereas they aired during the second fiscal quarter last year. Higher programming and production costs also reflects contractual rate increases for key sports rights, including the NFL and College Football, partially offset by the absence of rights costs with NASCAR.
Advertising revenue at ESPN was up almost 25% in the quarter, reflecting the timing of the 6  ball games, as well as a strong advertising marketplace for sports in general. We estimate that ESPN's ad revenue would have been up about 14% adjusted for the timing of the ball games, in the absence of NASCAR. Underlying ad trends remain very strong. However, due to the timing of the College Football Playoff, ad sales are pacing down in the second quarter versus prior year.
Broadcasting operating income was down in the first quarter as growth in affiliate and advertising revenue was more than offset by higher programming costs and increased equity losses from our investments in Hulu. Ad revenue at the ABC Network was up 8% in the first quarter due to an increase in units sold, higher rates and shift in the timing of New Year's Eve programming to Q1, offset somewhat may lower rating. So far this quarter, scatter pricing at the network is pacing high teens above upfront levels.
Media Networks affiliate revenue was up 4% in the first quarter, driven by a 7 percentage point increase in rate, partially offset by roughly a 2 percentage point decrease due to lower subs and a 2 point decrease from unfavorable foreign exchange rate. Broadcasting affiliate revenue was up more than the segment average, while cable affiliate revenue, adjusted for FX, was up approximately 3.5%. Recall that we have fully lapped the launch of the SEC Network and don't have any major affiliate agreement renewals in fiscal 2016. 
During the first quarter, we repurchased 21.1 million shares for $2.4 billion. Fiscal year-to-date, we have repurchased about 35.5 million shares for approximately $3.8 billion. 
Overall, we feel great about the start of the fiscal year. Our strategy of investing in high-quality content supported by the best brands in media continues to pay off. We are mindful of the evolutionary changes taking place in our industry and we feel we are well positioned to thrive in this evolving landscape due to the strength, depth and diversity of our businesses. 
And with that, I will now turn the call over to Lowell for Q&A

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we have our first question from UBS. We have Doug Mitchelson.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we have our first question from UBS. We have Doug Mitchelson.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess 2 questions. One, Bob, you outlined the the record results at Film, Consumer Products and Theme Parks. And I think investors are wondering, can it get any better than this? If you could help us understand what the drivers of this growth going forw
componenttext: I guess 2 questions. One, Bob, you outlined the the record results at Film, Consumer Products and Theme Parks. And I think investors are wondering, can it get any better than this? If you could help us understand what the drivers of this growth going forward in the business might be. I know Tom brought us through all the content that's coming. But are there particular initiatives that increased efficiency or is this just you think content in the future will continue to be better and better? And then any clarification on the cable network affiliate growth, 3.5% ex-FX. Are you guys confident as you as you look forward to that revenue growth in the Cable Networks business will be in line to ahead of sort of operating expenses on a go-forward basis if that makes sense?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're not going to give guidance, Doug, but I'll start by saying as a response to the second part of your question, that we fully expect our Media Networks, including ESPN, to continue to deliver bottom-line growth which means that revenue growth is go
componenttext: So we're not going to give guidance, Doug, but I'll start by saying as a response to the second part of your question, that we fully expect our Media Networks, including ESPN, to continue to deliver bottom-line growth which means that revenue growth is going to outpace spending. Obviously, we're not going to give guidance on Film and Parks and Consumer Products, but I think you should look at a few things. First of all, the intellectual property cycle is not only robust, but in some cases, really still growing. If you look at Star Wars and you look at Marvel as examples of that. But we've learned incredible pipeline, as Tom outlined earlier, at Pixar and Disney Animated Films and Disney live-action. We also know that those films drive a lot of this is across Parks and Resorts and Consumer Products. So I would say that the studio will continue to provide more growth opportunities for the company, and that includes growth internationally because China continues to grow as a market. Consumer Products is really a great story for this quarter because that is one business that while it did benefit significantly from Star Wars, we also saw continued success from other franchises and growth, notably Marvel which is a great sign. We expected that Star Wars was going to cannibalize some of our other franchises more and it didn't materialize. And lastly of the Parks front, we have obviously plan to build out, domestically rebuilding Avatar Land and we are building breaking ground, in fact, soon on Star Wars Land in 2 Domestic parks. And with Shanghai coming on board in June, while there are startup costs this year, you can expect that that's going to drive growth for Parks and Resorts for many years to come. So we feel really good about how all 4 of our businesses are positioned. And then I think you have to also consider with the media landscape looks like, and that is that there is a voracious appetite for high-quality intellectual property, particularly branded. And there isn't a new platform that launches that is not interested in licensing or gaining access to our channels are to our intellectual property. And we believe that we're going to see continued expansion across the world in new platforms and that will create opportunities for us to grow.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

Bob, can you just go back and clear up the differences the answer you gave in August about what you thought the source of ESPN subscribers and clients were versus what Schipper said in the journal about skinny bundles? We wanted to understand how much you think cord cutting versus skinny bundles. I want to put those 2 comments together?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was a timing issue. At the time that I made the comments last August, we were seeing some sub erosion from both sides from skinny bundles and from essentially a decrease in the total number of subs. At the time, because of where -- what Nielsen wa
componenttext: Yes, it was a timing issue. At the time that I made the comments last August, we were seeing some sub erosion from both sides from skinny bundles and from essentially a decrease in the total number of subs. At the time, because of where -- what Nielsen was telling us, we concluded that most of it was coming from simple loss of subs. Once Nielsen corrected those numbers, reducing the loss of subs by some 2 million subscribers -- or 2 million households, I should say, that we concluded that at that point, our sub losses which largely due to the fact that ESPN was not part of skinny bundles that has launched.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay and then you mentioned this $3 billion Star Wars consumer products. One of the questions we wanted to understand is what it do you think the tale is on Star Wars? Will it look like Frozen where it will get stronger as consumers become more familiar w
componenttext: Okay and then you mentioned this $3 billion Star Wars consumer products. One of the questions we wanted to understand is what it do you think the tale is on Star Wars? Will it look like Frozen where it will get stronger as consumers become more familiar with the product? Or do you think it's more akin to project release dates of these movies?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look -- Star Wars has always been one of the most popular franchises in the world. And when we acquired it in 2012 all the way up to September, we continue to see -- we saw some pretty robust sales of Star Wars merchandise, even though a film had no
componenttext: Well, look -- Star Wars has always been one of the most popular franchises in the world. And when we acquired it in 2012 all the way up to September, we continue to see -- we saw some pretty robust sales of Star Wars merchandise, even though a film had not been in the marketplace since 2005. So we knew that when we brought a film out, it was going to greatly enhance sales of Star Wars merchandise and not only did it do that, but it did well beyond what our expectations were. Don't forget, we did not bring new merchandise out for Star Wars until September 4. And the movie came out in December, so we're still seeing quite a significant tale even in this quarter from the sale of Star Wars merchandise across the world. And by the way, one thing that's very interesting is, that is not just a U.S. phenomenon. And in fact, we saw some pretty interesting Consumer Products is even in markets where the movie didn't perform, as well as either we had hoped or, as well as other markets. So with Rogue One coming out at the end of this year and then Star Wars VIII and IX planned for '17 and -- meaning, calendar year, and for '19 there's a standalone film. And then we think that -- while I don't want to predict it's going to be steady state, that we're not seen just something aberrational right now. But what we're seeing is the establishment of an old franchise but at a much higher level in terms of global interest and sales.

And then a follow-up on cable, just wanted to check and make sure you're still comfortable without icing legit affiliate revenue CAGR over the next 3-year guidance?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alexia, it's Tom. Let me talk about parks. Bob mentioned that we've got -- we've broken ground on 2 Star Wars Land. And of course, we think that's going to been a nice catalyst down the road. Before that, we'll open Avatar Land at Walt Disney World. So we
componenttext: Alexia, it's Tom. Let me talk about parks. Bob mentioned that we've got -- we've broken ground on 2 Star Wars Land. And of course, we think that's going to been a nice catalyst down the road. Before that, we'll open Avatar Land at Walt Disney World. So we have a cadence new attractions here domestically that we think guests will really embrace. I think -- we also see opportunities given the strong occupancy and room nights that we see you to consider expanding our hotel capacity down the road. So I think there are many avenues for us to continue to grow that business. Of course Bob talked about Shanghai and the growth of that will drive for us internationally. And remember that, while we open this in June, we also have significant room for expansion there over time. So we believe that the good news is that guests continue to really embrace our product. We think there's room to grow that product and continue to expand.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: From Bank of America Merrill Lynch, we have Jessica Reif Cohen.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two different questions. On Theme Parks, U.S. demand seems insatiable year-over-year driven by obviously your intellectual property in new attractions. With China 4 months away and you guys seem very, very excited about it. How different -- I mean I know
componenttext: Two different questions. On Theme Parks, U.S. demand seems insatiable year-over-year driven by obviously your intellectual property in new attractions. With China 4 months away and you guys seem very, very excited about it. How different -- I mean I know you do tons of studies of the market, how different do you think Chinese consumers will be over the long term not just into the opening?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jessica, all of our research tells us that our intellectual property and our guest service and our parks experience will resonate extremely well with our Chinese guests. At the same time, we've taken great care to make sure we design Shanghai specif
componenttext: Well, Jessica, all of our research tells us that our intellectual property and our guest service and our parks experience will resonate extremely well with our Chinese guests. At the same time, we've taken great care to make sure we design Shanghai specifically for that marketplace in terms of the layout of the park, the food that we're serving, the type and scripting of the shows that we're putting on. So we are definitely adapting to that market. But we have real confidence that it's going to be a product that's going to resonate and resonate for generations to come.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then the second question, ESPN obviously at hyperfocus by the market. Can you just talk little bit about the drivers are recent sub growth coming from pay-TV? Is it more collaboration between the programmers and distributors? And secondly
componenttext: Okay, great. And then the second question, ESPN obviously at hyperfocus by the market. Can you just talk little bit about the drivers are recent sub growth coming from pay-TV? Is it more collaboration between the programmers and distributors? And secondly, are you closed your minimum thresholds with pay-TV operators? Meaning, like -- should we be concerned that in your next cycle of contract negotiations, you heard we heard you said none this year, but are there any concern that the next go-round will be more difficult?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't know exactly what the drivers are for what were for the uptick that we've seen recently in terms of sub growth. We believe that we benefited from the growth of certain light packages that ESPN has been part of, particularly DISH. But I think you
componenttext: We don't know exactly what the drivers are for what were for the uptick that we've seen recently in terms of sub growth. We believe that we benefited from the growth of certain light packages that ESPN has been part of, particularly DISH. But I think you have to conclude that sports is very, very popular in this country. And when you look at the percentage of people that access sports on television and across markets and then access it across platforms that access it on ESPN, it's among the most, if not the most, popular programming out there. In fact, if you look at the studies that we've done among distributors, there's #1 and #2 in terms of value creation for them for 16 straight years. If you ask consumers, they say the same thing. It's #1 or #2 in terms of them were valuable channels that they get. So I actually believe and I know you want to know about the force in terms of our agreements, but he actually believe that this notion that either the expanded basic bundle is experiencing its demise or that ESPN is cratering in any way from a sub perspective is just ridiculous. Sports is too popular and it's not just that ESPN, just look at how the Super Bowl bid for instance, which I realize is a penultimate event. But day-after-day, week-after-weak, month-after-month, year-after-year live sports ends up being among the most highest rated programs across television. And ESPN has this incredible, as you know, an incredible set of license agreements with all the major sports, got the best venue out live sports that is out there, so we actually feel good about it. We were trying to do know is we are teaching with virtually all of the traditional platform owners and pushing ESPN into light packages and the success that DISH has experienced we think is a great selling point in that regard. At the same token, we're also looking at other opportunities with new platform providers that are emerging in the marketplace. We don't comment on our relationship, with a contractual relationship the distribution is but so we have not really touched on the so-called floor element of those agreements in about 15 years. And we do not foresee, by the way, that the next round of negotiations, whenever they are, are going to be particularly difficult for us because we come to the table just with ESPN along with a product that people love. And the other thing to note is the value of it from an advertising perspective. ESPN's advertising ad pacing, as Christine mentioned, has been tremendous. And if you look over the last 6 years, is advertising growth is 3x the growth in television advertising. So you have a product that's great for distributors, it's great for consumers and it's great for advertisers. And I believe really -- I guess with great confidence that it's going to thrive in whatever new world media world order we're experiencing.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Crédit Suisse, we have Omar Sheikh.
componenttext: From Crédit Suisse, we have Omar Sheikh.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm going to surprise you by not asking a question about ESPN. I've got a couple of questions. First, to both -- first to Bob, if I can and that's on Hulu. I wanted, Bob, if you could just sort of update us on your current thinking on Hulu. I mean, how
componenttext: So I'm going to surprise you by not asking a question about ESPN. I've got a couple of questions. First, to both -- first to Bob, if I can and that's on Hulu. I wanted, Bob, if you could just sort of update us on your current thinking on Hulu. I mean, how our sort of sub's going right now? Where do you think that business can get to in terms of subscribers and Domestic U.S. market? How do you think of and potential international expansion? How does it fit into the Disney strategy? I'd be interested to hear your thoughts on that. And then the second question on -- for Christine, maybe. Christine, you mentioned there was some startup or preopening costs in Shanghai. I wondered if you could just update us on what that number was in the quarter? How should we should think about perhaps phasing of those costs in the current quarter as well?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're bullish on Hulu and that's reflected in the level of investment that we and our other partners are putting into Hulu. First of all, we like new platforms. We like their appeal to young people particularly millennials. Clearly, the user interface and
componenttext: We're bullish on Hulu and that's reflected in the level of investment that we and our other partners are putting into Hulu. First of all, we like new platforms. We like their appeal to young people particularly millennials. Clearly, the user interface and the mobility of these new platforms is really attractive. It's also good platform to license our product too and we've actually derived a fair amount of revenue from doing that. And we believe we are going to continue to invest in Hulu and although I don't want to speak for Hulu completely, their investment strategy is going to be different to you to license off-network, movies, et cetera, but also to throw their original programming which they're doing nicely. I don't want to speculate where Hulu goes, but it fits very well into Disney strategy in terms of our investment in new technology platforms. And our support of new distribution opportunities.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Hi, Omar, it's Christine, on the Shanghai question. Back on our last conference call he said preopening costs would -- you should expect them to be in the $300 million range. Now that's an annual number that we've not broken them down by quarter but
componenttext: Okay. Hi, Omar, it's Christine, on the Shanghai question. Back on our last conference call he said preopening costs would -- you should expect them to be in the $300 million range. Now that's an annual number that we've not broken them down by quarter but you can expect those preopening costs to ramp into the open which is going to be in mid-June. And also, given that will be fully operational for little more than 3 months during the year, the pre-operating -- preopening expenses will impact the full year results.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: For Morgan Stanley, we have Ben Swinburne.
componenttext: For Morgan Stanley, we have Ben Swinburne.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: Christine, can you just help us think about expense growth at cable through the rest of the fiscal year? You mentioned you've now passed the College Football so the peak growth is now behind us, but just how should we be thinking about the rest of the year? And and related, Bob I'm just trying to square the subscriber growth comment with the subscriber headwinds in the Q. I think part of this maybe we're talking Nielsen and then paid subs. But are you saying you expect the subscriber headwinds to abate as you move through the next few quarters? Is that what you're saying or am I reading too much into that?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second part of the question and Christine could take the first. What I was talking about in terms of an uptick was recent. So the uptick that we talked about really didn't have that much of an impact in this quarter. So what we believe we've
componenttext: I'll take the second part of the question and Christine could take the first. What I was talking about in terms of an uptick was recent. So the uptick that we talked about really didn't have that much of an impact in this quarter. So what we believe we've seen our what we have seen recently is that subscriber trends going in the negative direction have abated somewhat. We're not making any pernicious about them going forward because we really don't know. We just feel great about the product and we believe that again, the predictions that many have made are more dire than they should be.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Ben, on the cable programming costs, as we said in the last conference call, we expect fiscal '16 cable programming and production cost to be up low to mid-single digits. And we are managing outside of the production -- well, the programming costs,
componenttext: Okay. Ben, on the cable programming costs, as we said in the last conference call, we expect fiscal '16 cable programming and production cost to be up low to mid-single digits. And we are managing outside of the production -- well, the programming costs, we are managing aggressive the other costs at ESPN.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Nomura, we have Anthony DiClemente.
componenttext: From Nomura, we have Anthony DiClemente.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: First for Christine -- Christine or Bob, just thinking about the Disney balance sheet, it's the strongest in the media industry, it's stronger than most companies in the United States. And when you look at what's going on in the economy -- in the media ec
componenttext: First for Christine -- Christine or Bob, just thinking about the Disney balance sheet, it's the strongest in the media industry, it's stronger than most companies in the United States. And when you look at what's going on in the economy -- in the media economy broadly, do you think about your balance sheet as a competitive advantage in anyway? And more specifically, what are the things that you can do to utilize the Disney balance sheet, not only financially but also strategically, whether it'd be more acquisition of IP, whether it'd be incremental capital spending on positive ROI projects or whether it'd be being opportunistic with a stock buybacks given some of the dislocation in the market?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony. Yes, when you look at the Disney balance sheet, it is the strongest in the media space, there's no question about that. We do view it as an asset. And when we look at the things that we could do that, your list of acquisitions investing i
componenttext: Thanks, Anthony. Yes, when you look at the Disney balance sheet, it is the strongest in the media space, there's no question about that. We do view it as an asset. And when we look at the things that we could do that, your list of acquisitions investing in our own businesses, having the flexibility to increase buyback, my answer to that would be all of the above. So we do look at this at the leverage that we have which is a little over 1x. The credit rating that we have which is on the single A rating it's all being very beneficial for us to be very flexible for all sorts of opportunities, as you indicated.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then one for Bob, just given the divergence in may be the narrative at least between the non-media side of Disney and the Media Networks side, I wonder what Disney ever consider separating its businesses into 2, with cable and broadcast on 1 side and
componenttext: And then one for Bob, just given the divergence in may be the narrative at least between the non-media side of Disney and the Media Networks side, I wonder what Disney ever consider separating its businesses into 2, with cable and broadcast on 1 side and studio parks Consumer Products and interactive in the other. I guess with the question is getting at is, we beat you can set up reminders of the synergies between the Media Networks and the non-media businesses at Disney.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm not going to talk about separating those assets. We fully expect that our media assets are going to continue to contribute to our growth. We also are designed as a company to leverage intellectual property across a lot of our businesses, or to leve
componenttext: So I'm not going to talk about separating those assets. We fully expect that our media assets are going to continue to contribute to our growth. We also are designed as a company to leverage intellectual property across a lot of our businesses, or to leverage the collection of brands nicely in the marketplace. And that also is reflected in the way we operate the businesses from an expense perspective with consolidation in many different areas. So if you look at the profile of the company interestingly enough since 2009 look at the growth profile, the company's grown on a compounded basis by 14%. The Media Networks have driven about 8% compound in the year and the rest of the company grew 23%. So 8% a year is pretty strong, 23% is extraordinary, 14% pretty damn strong, too. I think what that says is really is that over that period of time, we've actually diversified our ability to generate growth and profitability and that was very purposeful. These investments that we meet in Pixar, in Marvel and in Lucasfilm and the investments that we've made in our parks were designed for us to diversify our bottom line or our growth. And not just across businesses but really across the world because a lot of these businesses are global in nature unlike some of our media assets.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Citigroup, we have Jason Bazinet.
componenttext: From Citigroup, we have Jason Bazinet.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick question for Ms. McCarthy. When I look at the buybacks, I think and was a record dollar amount last quarter and second-highest the quarter you just printed. Should investors view that decision to buy back as much stock as you are a function of wha
componenttext: A quick question for Ms. McCarthy. When I look at the buybacks, I think and was a record dollar amount last quarter and second-highest the quarter you just printed. Should investors view that decision to buy back as much stock as you are a function of what you think the intrinsic value of your equity is relative to what it's trading at, or is it more a function of the very lean balance sheet and a lack of M&A opportunities, i.e. other better uses for your cash?.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jason. That way we buy back our stock, we do keep an eye on our intrinsic value. So obviously our -- the amount of stock we bought is an indication that we believe that our stock is a great investment and it is well below that intrinsic value. The
componenttext: Thanks, Jason. That way we buy back our stock, we do keep an eye on our intrinsic value. So obviously our -- the amount of stock we bought is an indication that we believe that our stock is a great investment and it is well below that intrinsic value. The strength of the balance sheet does afford us a lot of flexibility so we're able to react to these opportunities especially when the market this locates in our name or the market over all. So we have taken opportunities to be aggressive so far this year then we intend to do it going forward for the balance of the year.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: Bob, I want to pick up on the comment you just made, if you don't mind. I was actually playing with the math myself. You talked about the 14% since 2009 and the different components of that. Is it wrong to think then that you talked about sort of an organic growth rate, I'll call it high singles, and then obviously great contributions from both organic investments in the parks and M&A delivered something like 14% total growth for the company. So thinking forward from here, should rethink about the company is a high single grower or do you think assets you've put in place gets you to that double-digit rate that you've had for the past 5-plus years? Or more M&A investment be required? How should we think through the national growth rate from here?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You should think nothing but happy thoughts about this company. I don't know what else to say. We're not going to give any guidance whatsoever. We believe that we have distinguished ourselves in the media sector, not only with our growth these last number
componenttext: You should think nothing but happy thoughts about this company. I don't know what else to say. We're not going to give any guidance whatsoever. We believe that we have distinguished ourselves in the media sector, not only with our growth these last number of years, but with the assets that we've collected and with the growth potential that we've created for this company going forward and we'll leave it at that.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I didn't mean to ask an unfair question, I understand. Given that, I think...
componenttext: I didn't mean to ask an unfair question, I understand. Given that, I think...

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I didn't think it is unfair, but we're just, as you know, we're not going to go there. But I do think it's important, and I don't mean to be too wordy, but if you look at the profile of the company, we have 4 businesses that are going to deliver growth fo
componenttext: I didn't think it is unfair, but we're just, as you know, we're not going to go there. But I do think it's important, and I don't mean to be too wordy, but if you look at the profile of the company, we have 4 businesses that are going to deliver growth for this company, Parks and Resorts, Media Networks, the Studio and Consumer Products. And there was a time not that long ago where we were getting growth really from just a couple of for them. And some, like the studio, somewhat lumpy in nature. Meaning there were good years and bad based on the slate. I'm not suggesting that every year we grow because there will be ups and downs in some cases, but they will be much flatter in nature. Meaning, you can expect that the bottom-line contribution from the businesses will continue on essentially on a more consistent basis than they were -- than what you saw in the past.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, on Hulu, can you talk about -- you mentioned you're confident, you feel good about it, why -- help us understand why you're not concerned that at the $12 price point for the ad free version that it doesn't represent a cannibalization
componenttext: Two questions. First, on Hulu, can you talk about -- you mentioned you're confident, you feel good about it, why -- help us understand why you're not concerned that at the $12 price point for the ad free version that it doesn't represent a cannibalization risk to your core business. And in second, if we can talk about the affiliate growth number, the 4% you just reported, most of your peers and have television stations have growth significantly above that in their retransmission fees. And I'm curious, are you seeing a higher rate in retransmission in there for a lower rate on the cable side? What's the balance between those components when we look at the 4%?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you want to address that?
componenttext: Do you want to address that?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that -- Christine took you through the relative growth on the affiliate fees, and we're very pleased with where we've been going on their retransmission side of the equation. In fact, we're well ahead of the guidance we give some time ago an
componenttext: Well, I think that -- Christine took you through the relative growth on the affiliate fees, and we're very pleased with where we've been going on their retransmission side of the equation. In fact, we're well ahead of the guidance we give some time ago and expect that growth to continue, so we feel very good about that and the relative contribution between the 2. So I don't really want to address the nature of the growth and other companies the mix is often different in their coming off of different basis as well. So with regard to Hulu. Look, the Hulu business model has evolved the return continues to. We noticed we have noticed they've added subscribers rather nicely. That has not been overly driven by the ad-fee portion of the equation. That's actually a small part of the subscriber base. At this point, were not overly concerned with the impact of that to the ecosystem as a whole. We'll obviously keep our eye on it. And is Bob indicated previously, he take a balanced approach to both those businesses and then also how we think about positioning our programming within them. And we'll continue to do that.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just back to the first question or I guess my second on the growth rate. Was there anything unusual in the first quarter that impacted that 4% growth rate, or is that as you look at what we're seeing right now a fair run rate maybe with a
componenttext: Great. And then just back to the first question or I guess my second on the growth rate. Was there anything unusual in the first quarter that impacted that 4% growth rate, or is that as you look at what we're seeing right now a fair run rate maybe with a little bit of variance either FX or for the subscriber numbers that Bob referenced?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think Christine's comments pretty much summarized this. So I wouldn't say there's anything unusual. Obviously, the foreign exchange impact is something that we wouldn't expect to see continue year-over-year, depending clearly where foreign exchange
componenttext: Yes, I think Christine's comments pretty much summarized this. So I wouldn't say there's anything unusual. Obviously, the foreign exchange impact is something that we wouldn't expect to see continue year-over-year, depending clearly where foreign exchange goes. But other than that -- and also as mobs indicated, some of the trends that we see on the subscriber side have shown, at least initial signs of abating somewhat and we'll watch those very carefully.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: From FBR Capital Markets, we have Barton Crockett.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the comment earlier that you can have growth in earnings at Media Networks, even with this kind of lower affiliate fee growth trajectory. I was wondering if you could tell us given what we know from the step up in sports rights, I kn
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the comment earlier that you can have growth in earnings at Media Networks, even with this kind of lower affiliate fee growth trajectory. I was wondering if you could tell us given what we know from the step up in sports rights, I know you don't want to guide, but qualitatively are we looking at cost cutting or are we looking at other revenues coming into kind of makeup the gap for the sports rights costs pressure that we see coming up?

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Bart, I just the context that I'd give you that is first of all, you've seen a we've successfully grown our advertising revenues and especially with a branded services and programming that we have, we continue to get a good response from advertisers
componenttext: Well, Bart, I just the context that I'd give you that is first of all, you've seen a we've successfully grown our advertising revenues and especially with a branded services and programming that we have, we continue to get a good response from advertisers, both on our linear channels and on new platform, so that looks good. I think that trend will continue. I think we've done -- we've discussed the affiliate side of the equation. The only other thing to keep in mind is that as new sports contracts kick in next year as an example, that will sometimes cause a shift in terms about the growth is coming, but the overall growth story is intact. And I think that gives you what color is available there.

headline: The Walt Disney Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext:
Barton, thanks for the question. And thanks, again everyone for joining us today. Note that a reconciliation of non-GAAP measures that were referred to on this call to equivalent GAAP measures can be found on our Investor Relations website. Let me also remind you that certain statements on this call may constitute forward-looking statements under the securities laws. We make these statements on the basis of our views and assumptions regarding future events and business performance at the time we make them, and we do not undertake any obligation to update these statements. Forward-looking statements are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties and actual results may differ materially from the results expressed or implied in light of a variety of factors, including factors contained in our annual report on Form 10-K and our other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
This concludes today's call. Have a great rest of the day, everyone.
